main_levels.name: Letter Sounds
main_levels.description: Sounds of letters combined with diacritics

main_levels.name: Keyboard
main_levels.description: Type letters on the Arabic keyboard

main_levels.name: Combine letters
main_levels.description: Identify the letters that make any word

main_levels.name: Vocabulary
main_levels.description: Read, Write and Listen to 50 words

sounds_sublevels.name: ا ء أ إ آ ى

diacritics_sublevels.name: short vowels
diacritics_sublevels.description: Short Vowels (fat7ah, kasrah and dammah) and Sukoon

diacritics_sublevels.name: tanween
diacritics_sublevels.description: adding "n" sound at the end of words

alvl1.description: Let's learn the names and shapes of Arabic alphabet letters
First Letter of the Arabic alphabet, can be combined with hamzah
glottal stop, as in the sound uh-oh, we use the number 2 to refer to its sound
alif with maddah (long aa sound), and has hamzah sound if within the word

alvl3.description: 7aa2 is closer to "h" , but sounds different, so we use 7
khaa2 is closer to "k", but differennt, we use "kh"

alvl4.description: dhaal has the sound of "th" in the word "that"

alvl5.description: Saad has a sound closer to "s" but more emphatic, we use capital S
Daad has a sound close to "d", but more emphatic, we use capital D

alvl6.description: Taa2 has a sound close to "t", but more emphatic, we use capital T
Dhaa2 has a sound close to "dh", but more emphatic, we use capital DH
3ayn is close to "a", but different, we use the letter 3
ghayn is close to "g" but different, we use "gh" to refer to its sound

alvl7.description: qaaf has a sound close to "k", but more emphatic, we use q

alvl10.description: taa2 marbootah comes at the end of the word, and is pronounced as "h" if there is a pause after the word, otherwise it is pronounced "t" as regular taa2
hamzah on waaw, has the glottal stop sound 2 following the "u" sound
hamzah 'ala nabrah has the glottal stop sound 2 following "i" sound

alvl11.description: alif layyenah has the same sound of alif "aa", but it comes at the end of words

alvl11.letter_shapes: لا ـلا لأ ـلأ لإ ـلإ لآ ـلآ
alvl11.description: laam alif is a combination of laam + alif, and they both take different shape. The alif can be combined with hamzah or maddah

slvl1.description: alif without hamzah commonly appears in the middle of the word, with "aa" sound
alif without hamzah can occur in the beginning of the word with kasrah or dammah
If alif without hamzah comes at the end of the word, it can often be alif layyenah
hamzah sounds like a glottal stop as in uh-oh, we use number 2 to indicate its sound
alif with hamzah above can have fat7ah (by default)
alif with hamzah above can have sukoon (mainly within a word)
alif with hamzah above can have dammah
alif with hamzah below has kasrah by default.
alif with maddah is hamzah + alif, which sounds as a long alif preceded by hamzah sound
alif with maddah can appear also in the middle of the word, with clearer hamzah sound

slvl3.description: 7aa2 is closer to "h" , but sounds different, so we use 7
khaa2 is closer to "k", but differennt, we use "kh"

slvl4.description: dhaal has the sound of "th" in the word "that"

slvl5.description: Saad has a sound closer to "s" but more emphatic, we use capital S
Daad has a sound close to "d", but more emphatic, we use capital D

slvl6.description: Taa2 has a sound close to "t", but more emphatic, we use capital T
Dhaa2 has a sound close to "dh", but more emphatic, we use capital DH
3ayn is close to "a", but different, we use the letter 3
ghayn is close to "g" but different, we use "gh" to refer to its sound

slvl7.description: qaaf has a sound close to "k", but more emphatic, we use q

slvl10.description: taa2 marbootah has the "h" sound, but in some contexts it sounds as "t"
hamzah becomes hamzah 'ala waaw if the letter before it has dammah
hamzah becomes hamzah 'ala nabrah if the letter before it has kasrah

dlvl1.description: Diacritics are added to the letters to define their sounds, let's learn about them
The diacritic fat7ah is the short "a" vowel
The diacritic kasrah is the short "i" vowel
The diacritic dammah is the short "u" vowel
The diacritic sukoon indicates there is no vowel. Absence of any diacritics can be equivalent to sukoon diacritic

dlvl2.description: The diacritic shaddah indicates doubling of the letter sound. It can be combined with short vowels
doubling of the sound combined with fat7ah
doubling of the sound combined with kasrah
doubling of the sound combined with dammah

dlvl3.description: some words have tanween with fat7ah, with double fat7ah diacritics that sounds as "an"
some indefinite words can be written with dammah tanween, which is a double dammah, that sounds as "un"
For some grammatical reasons, some indefinte words in sentences can have tanween with kasrah, which sounds as "in"
